articles.title: Trump ties crime with immigration, blurring the lines with Guard deployment
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details how President Trump has used the federalization of state National Guard forces to advance aggressive immigration enforcement, particularly in Democratic-led cities such as Chicago, Memphis, and Los Angeles. Despite legal prohibitions under the Posse Comitatus Act, which bans federal military from domestic policing, the administration has deployed National Guard troops to assist with immigration raids and guard federal agents. These actions are framed by Trump as efforts to combat crime driven by undocumented immigrants, though data show that such a link is unfounded. In reality, the deployments blur the lines between traditional law enforcement and immigration enforcement, creating widespread fear among residents, especially immigrants and U.S. citizens. Communities report confusion over who can arrest whom, as federal agents often wear military-style gear or masks. Legal experts argue that the pattern of deployments—often tied to protests and raids—forms a cycle where aggressive enforcement sparks unrest, which in turn justifies military intervention. Previous operations, such as Operation Lone Star in Texas, show a history of using military tactics against migrants. While the National Guard cannot make arrests, their presence has led to increased anxiety and legal challenges, including court rulings in California and ongoing appeals. The article underscores a growing concern that the administration is using militarized enforcement to legitimize its immigration policies, undermining civil liberties and community trust.
keyTakeAways: Trump’s administration has conflated illegal immigration and urban crime, leading to widespread National Guard deployments in cities like Chicago, Portland, Memphis, and Washington, D.C.
National Guard troops are deployed under federal authority, but they cannot legally make arrests — their role is often limited to guarding federal facilities or cleaning streets.
The deployments are frequently tied to immigration enforcement operations, including ICE raids at locations such as Home Depot stores and ICE processing facilities.

Local leaders and communities, especially immigrants and U.S. citizens, express fear and confusion about who is authorized to arrest or patrol, as federal agents often wear military-style gear or masks.
Legal experts note that the use of National Guard troops in domestic law enforcement violates the Posse Comitatus Act, which generally prohibits federal military from engaging in domestic policing.
The Trump administration has used the public reaction to protests and immigration raids as a pretext to deploy the Guard, creating a cycle of enforcement and unrest.

Prior to these deployments, Texas had already engaged in border operations using tear gas against migrant groups under 'Operation Lone Star,' indicating a pattern of militarized immigration enforcement.
In Illinois, Texas National Guard troops were briefly stationed at an ICE facility outside Chicago, though the deployment was temporarily blocked by a federal court.
In Washington, D.C., and Memphis, a significant portion of arrests are immigration-related, even if the National Guard does not make arrests.
The public and legal experts argue that the blurring of lines between law enforcement, immigration enforcement, and military presence undermines community safety and civil liberties.

articles.content:
Trump ties crime with immigration, blurring the lines with Guard deployment 
         By Kat Lonsdorf, Sergio Martínez-Beltrán 
        
           Friday, October 17, 2025 • 5:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         CHICAGO — It's a sunny October morning, and Yackson is waiting for a bus that will take him to meet his immigration attorney. The Venezuelan, who NPR is identifying by his first name because of his immigration status, looks at a big, run-down apartment building in front of him. Earlier this month, it was raided by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents who landed a helicopter on the roof, and arrested more than 30 people. Yackson, 39, says he's terrified. Besides this raid, he's also heard about the possibility of National Guard troops deploying here, something a federal court has put on hold for now. The father of three lives in this neighborhood and he's been scared to leave his house. "We already don't know who is grabbing us, whether it's ICE or whether it's people who disguise themselves as ICE," Yackson says in Spanish. "With the National Guard, it's going to be even harder, scarier." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In several cities across the country facing National Guard deployments, NPR has heard similar sentiment. "The government isn't exactly doing a great job of proactively delineating this person is National Guard who isn't allowed to arrest immigrants, and this person is an ICE agent or an FBI agent who is," says Dara Lind a senior fellow at the American Immigration Council, noting that many times federal agents are in military-style gear, or masked, or not clearly marked. She says this makes it hard to look at patrols on the street and figure out who is legally authorized to engage in law enforcement activities or not. Under U.S. law, the National Guard and other military personnel can't make arrests. But experts worry that the pattern of their deployments, alongside increased federal immigration raids and operations, has allowed for violent crime and illegal immigration to be conflated into a single crisis. The Guard's actual role in immigration enforcement in these deployments remains unclear. In September, the Trump administration announced a widespread ICE operation in Illinois called Operation Midway Blitz, saying it was needed to fight crime by undocumented immigrants. It came after Trump had been pressuring Democratic Illinois Governor JB Pritzker to deploy the state National Guard for the same reason, but Pritzker refused. After weeks of fighting between the two, Trump federalized the Illinois National Guard – a highly unusual move — and worked with Republican Texas Governor Greg Abbott to send hundreds of his state's Guard to Illinois. Part of Trump's continued rhetoric Trump has been  conflating crime and illegal immigration  since he first emerged on the political scene. It's something that has proved popular with his base — and helped garner support for his  unprecedented crackdown on immigrants . The net has swept up people living in the country illegally along with U.S. residents, people with visas, or those granted humanitarian parole. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The White House regularly characterizes undocumented immigrants as drivers of urban lawlessness,  even though the data show that is not true . Officials at the Department of Homeland Security and the White House constantly refer to ICE actions as only targeting " the worst of the worst ," a talking point that isn't  supported by the arrest data . "This is really, really core to the administration's immigration policy. They toggle between 'we're only going after these really, really bad criminals,' and 'we're deporting everybody who's in the country without authorization,'" says Lind. "They get to play that two-step because there's this bigger body of fears that they're playing into about urban areas as unsafe, as unruly, about there being some kind of unrest, and about protests being always akin to riots." Trump has deployed  the National Guard in five Democratic-led cities  so far — often over the objections of state and local leaders — claiming troops are needed to control crime and lawlessness, although data show that violent crime in many of those places has decreased in recent years. Some of those deployments — like in  Chicago  and  Portland, Ore.  — have been blocked by the courts and are making their way through a federal appeals process. But others are ongoing, like in Washington, D.C., and Memphis. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       These deployments have coincided with increased immigration raids which have, in effect, blurred the lines between traditional law enforcement, immigration enforcement and the role of the National Guard. In June,  Trump federalized California's National Guard  — against Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom's wishes – and sent in members of the U.S. Marine Corps to quell protests in Los Angeles in response to increased immigration and deportation raids in the city. There, protesters confined to an area of downtown Los Angeles clashed with federal agents. And ICE  often launched raids  at Home Depot stores and other locations across the city. A federal judge in California  later ruled  that the National Guard troops were being used illegally there, violating the  Posse Comitatus Act , a 19th-century law that bars the use of federal troops for domestic policing, except when "expressly authorized by the Constitution or Act of Congress." Trump appealed that ruling, and a hearing is expected later this month. Trump has also deployed troops to guard federal agents who are carrying out immigration enforcement operations. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In August, Trump sent National Guard troops into Washington, D.C., a unique place where Trump has the legal authority to do so, along with a flood of federal law enforcement agents, including ICE, which has carried out a  sizable chunk of the arrests . The next month,  Trump announced a similar operation in Memphis  — with the support of Republican Governor Bill Lee, who approved the use of Tennessee National Guard troops. The deployment started at the end of September and is ongoing. The operation also includes officials from more than a dozen federal agencies, including ICE, and has led to more than 800 arrests, according to the Department of Justice. While the DOJ has not released a breakdown of that data, Shelby County Mayor Lee Harris, who has been critical of the federal intervention,  noted at a press conference this week  that immigration offenses made up a significant portion of the arrests. Immigration and National Guard deployments are "deeply intertwined" In Illinois, Texas National Guard troops were briefly stationed at an ICE facility outside of Chicago, before their deployment was temporarily blocked. In D.C., troops have mainly been cleaning up streets and guarding federal buildings. In Memphis, they've been seen accompanying local law enforcement. But legal experts say there's a clear connection developing between Trump's use of the troops and his immigration enforcement tactics. "We see these as deeply intertwined," says Benjamin Farley, special counsel at the National Immigration Law Center, which advocates for immigrant rights. "The Trump administration is using an increasingly aggressive, increasingly brutal approach to immigration enforcement, which, unsurprisingly, inspires protests. And then the protests themselves serve as a pretext or an excuse for the Trump administration to deploy the National Guard and the Armed Forces of the United States," he says. The Texas National Guard — which has been federalized and deployed to Illinois, even as the deployment is challenged in court — has been involved in immigration-related operations in the past. In 2021, Gov. Abbott sent hundreds of troops to the Texas-Mexico border to assist in his multibillion dollar initiative called  Operation Lone Star . Among the tasks for the troops were repelling migrants and, at least in one instance, troops used tear gas on a group of Venezuelan migrants at the border. That operation is still ongoing. Scott R. Anderson, a fellow specializing in national security law at the non-partisan Brookings Institution, notes that the way Trump seems to be using the National Guard now — largely guarding federal property — is not as dramatic as a lot of the rhetoric surrounding the deployments. Still, he says that it is pushing the envelope of the law, and could gradually change with further deployments. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "I think precisely because it's unprecedented and because it's on uncertain legal territory, the administration is actually doing it kind of incrementally, they're not immediately jumping to the most severe thing they could be doing. And that makes just a more complicated picture, and it also complicates how you respond to it in a lot of ways," he says. But the legal grounds for the deployments aren't something many people caught up in them have the luxury of thinking about, says Lind of the American Immigration Council. For communities who are targeted and already frightened, taking the time to differentiate between the National Guard and a federal law enforcement agency is secondary to staying safe. "I don't think a whole lot of people are particularly interested in parsing the relationship between the National Guard and federal law enforcement," she says.  NPR's Marisa Peñaloza contributed to this report from Chicago.  
         
         Transcript 
         AILSA CHANG, HOST:   President Trump's National Guard deployments have been blurring the lines between crime patrols and illegal immigration enforcement. Guard troops have been sent to help with immigration enforcement, including securing federal ICE facilities and in some cases protecting ICE agents during raids. The White House frequently characterizes undocumented immigrants as drivers of urban lawlessness, even though the data shows that is not true. Here to talk about all of this is NPR's Sergio Martínez-Beltrán in Chicago and NPR's Kat Lonsdorf in D.C. Hey to both of you. KAT LONSDORF, BYLINE: Hey there. SERGIO MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN, BYLINE: Hey, Ailsa. CHANG: Sergio, let's start with you. Just catch us up on what's been happening on the ground in Chicago the last few days. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: Well, Ailsa, the National Guard is in Illinois. More specifically, the Texas National Guard is in Illinois, along with some federalized Illinois guard. But you won't see them out in the streets of Chicago, though. That's because a federal court temporarily blocked its deployment yesterday. Now, the only place that troops were sent in Illinois so far is an ICE processing facility outside of Chicago. I went there and not much was happening. CHANG: OK. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: Now, last month, ICE launched a new operation here in Chicago, claiming it was needed to fight off crime - something state and local leaders strongly refute. Chicago has its ongoing challenges with crime - right? - but the city's homicide rate this summer was the lowest since 1965. But this is what Trump has been doing since he first emerged on the political scene - deliberately conflating these ideas of crime and illegal immigration, which has proved popular with his base and helped to garner support for his unprecedented crackdown on immigrants - those in the country illegally and, in some cases, people who are U.S. residents or have visas. CHANG: OK. Well, Kat, you've been following these various National Guard deployments or threats of deployments the past few weeks. LONSDORF: Yeah. CHANG: Can you just talk about the larger pattern you're seeing here? LONSDORF: Yeah. I mean, Trump's conflation of crime and illegal immigration has been at the center of many of these deployments. We first saw it back in June, when Trump federalized California's National Guard against Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom's wishes. Trump did that to quell protests in Los Angeles in response to immigration and deportation raids in the city. The Guard was sent in to protect federal ICE facilities and personnel in that case too. And that's the same reasoning Trump has given for federalizing the Guard in Oregon as well, even though that is currently halted by the federal courts, too. Experts we've talked to say these National Guard deployments and the administration's immigration tactics are pretty intertwined right now. Here's Benjamin Farley with the National Immigration Law Center, which advocates for immigrant rights. BENJAMIN FARLEY: Using the aggressive and sort of brutal approach to immigration enforcement, generating a very expected reaction and then letting that reaction serve as a pretext for the deployment of armed forces. LONSDORF: And, you know, legally speaking, when the National Guard is federalized, which is the case in all these Democratic states where the governors have pushed back, they can't enforce state laws unless the governors say they can. CHANG: That's right. And let's be very clear here. Even if the president says that these troops are going to help fight crime in these various places, let's remember that the National Guard cannot make arrests. They cannot, like, join up with local law enforcement officers to fight crime, right? LONSDORF: Right. But they can help immigration enforcement even if they still can't make arrests because that's federal. Here's how Scott R. Anderson at the nonpartisan Brookings Institution explained it. SCOTT R ANDERSON: He's trying to get them to consent to doing a broader mission set. But until they do, he's doing this narrow one to focus on immigration law 'cause that's what he has the legal authority to do. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: And Ailsa, there's something else that's significant here. It was Texas Governor Greg Abbott who sent his National Guard troops to Illinois at Trump's request. And the Texas guard, contrary to other state guards, has been involved in immigration operations. Abbott sent troops to the Texas-Mexico border to repel migrants as part of a multibillion-dollar effort called Operation Lone Star. I mean, there's footage of troops using tear gas on a group of Venezuelan migrants at the border in 2024. So the Texas guard has done immigration-related work before, and that could impact how they'd operate if allowed to patrol on the streets here in Illinois. CHANG: But what about in places like Memphis, where the governor has approved the use of the National Guard, or in the case of D.C., where the guard is technically under the president's control? Like, how does all of that fit here? LONSDORF: Yeah, in both D.C. and Memphis, Trump has sent in various federal agencies and National Guard troops to fight crime. And federal law enforcement officials have made a lot of arrests in both those places, but a significant portion of them have been immigration-related. I talked with Maria Oceja. She's in Memphis. She's a community organizer and immigration advocate there. She says while other people in the city might have focused on Trump's message about fighting crime, immigrant communities were skeptical. MARIA OCEJA: We have been tracking the messaging that has been coming out of the White House, and so we are not fooled by this language of, oh, we're only going to Memphis to fight crime. LONSDORF: She says there's been a lot of confusion and fear in the community there. The guard's actual role in immigration enforcement in these deployments remains unclear. Again, they cannot legally make arrests. In D.C., they've mainly been cleaning up streets and guarding federal buildings. CHANG: OK. Well, Sergio, I know that you've been talking to people in Chicago all week. What have you been hearing from them? MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: Yeah. I mean, a lot of U.S.-born residents tell us that they are angry. They don't want the National Guard or federal immigration agents in their communities, especially because their tactics have become more aggressive, leading to the arrest of some U.S. citizens. And for undocumented immigrants, the terror is real. I talked to Jackson (ph), a Venezuelan immigrant who did not want us to use his last name because of his legal status. JACKSON: (Speaking Spanish). MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: He says that it's already been scary and challenging to live in the city where you don't know if the masked person arresting you is ICE or someone pretending to be. And with the National Guard in town, Jackson says it will be even worse. CHANG: That is NPR's Sergio Martínez-Beltrán in Chicago and Kat Lonsdorf in D.C. Thank you to both of you. LONSDORF: Thanks, Ailsa. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: You're welcome.

articles.title: Pickleball Eye Injuries Are on the Rise
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pickleball, now played by nearly 20 million Americans, has seen a sharp rise in eye injuries—up 405 cases annually from 2021 to 2024—according to a study published in JAMA Ophthalmology. The majority of injuries (70%) occur in adults 50 years or older, challenging the assumption that youth athletes are most at risk. Injuries stem from impacts with the ball, paddle, or falls due to the game’s fast pace and small court size. Experts including Dr. Corey Lacher and Dr. Daniel Henick emphasize that standard eye protection—especially shatter-resistant polycarbonate gear meeting ASTM F3164 standards—could prevent up to 90% of these injuries. A major barrier is lack of awareness among players, with many unaware of the risks. Recommendations include standardized guidelines, visible court signage, improved product accessibility, and role modeling by professional athletes. The study notes limitations, including a small sample and data from only participating emergency departments. Despite these, the key takeaway is the urgent need for public awareness and standardized safety protocols to prevent preventable, life-changing injuries.
keyTakeAways: The incidence of pickleball-related eye injuries has increased by an estimated 405 cases per year from 2021 to 2024.
70% of eye injury cases in pickleball occur in adults aged 50 or older, contrary to expectations that youth athletes are most at risk.
Eye injuries can result from being hit by the ball, paddle, or falling, due to the fast-paced and small-court nature of the game.
Standardized eye protection guidelines are recommended to prevent up to 90% of sports-related eye injuries, similar to those in squash.
Players are often unaware of the risks, and lack of awareness is a major reason for non-use of protective eyewear.
Recommended protective eyewear should be made of shatter-resistant polycarbonate and meet the American Society for Testing and Materials' F3164 standard.
The study's limitations include a small sample size and reliance on emergency department data from participating hospitals only.
The main takeaway is raising awareness of preventable injuries, which could be mitigated through simple interventions like standardized guidelines and better education.

articles.content:
Grab the goggles. Pickleball eye injuries are on the rise 
         By Arundathi Nair  
        
           Sunday, October 19, 2025 • 7:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         Pickleball has quickly become huge in the United States, with  nearly 20 million  people playing the sport. But that popularity comes with a price. With more people on the court, pickleball-related eye injuries, including lacerations around the eye, corneal abrasions and inflamed irises, have increased. A  study  published this week in  JAMA Ophthalmology  estimates that the incidence of these injuries has risen dramatically, going up by an estimated 405 cases each year from 2021 to 2024. Researchers looked at data from a representative population of patients in emergency departments across the U.S. to understand which pickleball players are especially vulnerable to eye injuries and how they occurred. From there, they estimated what those trends looked like on a national scale. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Given the "alarming" increase in eye injury cases, the study authors called for developing standardized guidelines for eye protection, which has been found to reduce up to  90% of sports-related  eye injuries. Other sports such as squash have mandated such guidelines. The study found that 70% of cases were in adults 50 years or older. Dr. Natasha Desai, the co-director for the Center for Women's Sports Medicine at NYU Langone, was surprised to see this finding because a large share of  sports-related injuries  occur in young players. Desai, who wasn't involved in this study, doesn't think the sport is necessarily getting more dangerous. "More people are playing, so there's going to be more injuries at a higher volume," she says. And there are a lot of ways you can get injured in pickleball, notes Dr. Corey Lacher, an ophthalmologist resident at Rutgers New Jersey Medical School and the paper's lead author, including getting hit by the ball, a paddle or by falling. "A lot of people think that just because it's a wiffle ball that you're not going to get hurt," he says. But, it's still risky because "everything is very fast-paced in pickleball and you're playing on a very small court." However, getting players to wear eye protection is easier said than done, as Desai points out. It's another piece of equipment players have to purchase and bring with them. And with so many options on the market, choosing a pair can be daunting. Players would benefit from standardized eye protection guidelines for pickleball, says Lacher. "There's $10 pickleball eye protection and there's $160. How do you know which one to buy?" If you're shopping for eyewear, Lacher and Desai recommend products made of shatter-resistant polycarbonate and those that meet the American Society for Testing and Materials's  F3164 standard . Dr. Daniel Henick, an ophthalmology resident at Yale School of Medicine and an avid pickleball player, has  been researching  which groups of players are wearing eye protection and why the rest aren't. He says one of the most common reasons players don't use protective eyewear is that they aren't aware of the risks. Henick says that having standardized guidelines, posting them outside of courts for players to see, making eye-protection more user-friendly, and encouraging professional pickleball athletes to set an example for the influx of new players could help reduce injuries. The paper points out its limitations are having a small sample size and relying on a database that only includes emergency departments that opt in to the data collection. But Lacher sees the main takeaway from the study as bringing awareness to these injuries. Henick agrees, noting these injuries can sometimes be life-changing: "We're talking about hundreds, if not thousands, of injuries every year that could be prevented with what could be a relatively simple intervention." USA Pickleball did not reply to a request for comment on the study's call for eye-protection guidelines.

articles.title: Thieves Strike Louvre Museum, Stealing Napoleonic Jewels in Daylight Heist
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a rare daylight heist at the Louvre museum in Paris, thieves used a basket lift to breach the riverfront facade, forcing a window and stealing eight valuable Napoleonic-era items, including the emerald-set imperial crown of Empress Eugénie. The theft, which occurred just 250 meters from the Mona Lisa, was described as a professional 'four-minute operation' and highlights serious security flaws in a museum already under strain from overcrowding and understaffing. Eight objects, including royal crowns, necklaces, and brooches, were taken; one crown was found broken outside. The incident has sparked political criticism, with far-right leader Jordan Bardella blaming government failure, while officials stress ongoing security upgrades under the 'Louvre New Renaissance' plan. Experts believe the stolen jewels may never be recovered due to professional re-cutting. This event underscores both the vulnerability of iconic cultural institutions and the urgent need for improved security and staffing.

articles.title: U.S. Expands DACA and Introduces Reentry Policy for Deported Individuals
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. government has announced a significant shift in immigration policy by expanding the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program to include new applicants and introducing a new reentry policy for individuals who have been deported but are now seeking to return to the United States. These changes, effective from April 15, 2023, are part of a broader effort to provide stability and legal protections for undocumented immigrants, particularly those who arrived as children. The expansion of DACA reflects a more inclusive approach to immigration, while the reentry policy signals a potential shift in enforcement practices, emphasizing humanitarian considerations. These developments are expected to have significant implications for the lives of thousands of individuals affected by immigration policies.
keyTakeAways: The expansion of DACA to include new applicants reflects a shift in U.S. immigration policy towards providing stability and legal protections for undocumented individuals who arrived as children.
The reentry policy for previously deported individuals shows a potential shift in how the U.S. handles immigration enforcement and humanitarian considerations.

articles.title: Ukrainian Drone Strikes on Russian Energy Facilities Spark Escalation Amid U.S. Peace Proposal Shift
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, Ukrainian drones struck the Orenburg gas processing plant in southern Russia, damaging a key facility operated by Gazprom and disrupting gas intake from Kazakhstan. The attack has been linked to Ukraine’s broader strategy of targeting Russian energy infrastructure to weaken the war effort. In retaliation, Russian forces reportedly launched 62 drones into Ukraine, with several strikes occurring near Kharkiv and Dnipropetrovsk, including a long-range rocket bomb attack on Lozava, raising concerns about civilian casualties. Ukrainian officials claim to have also damaged Russia’s Novokuibyshevsk oil refinery. Meanwhile, U.S. President Donald Trump suggested in a Fox News interview that Ukraine may need to give up territory in exchange for peace, marking a significant shift from previous support for Ukrainian territorial restoration. Trump also declined to commit to supplying Ukraine with Tomahawk missiles, citing U.S. defense needs. Diplomatic efforts are ongoing, with talks between Trump, Putin, and Zelenskyy expected in Hungary, though no major breakthroughs are anticipated.
keyTakeAways: Ukrainian drones struck a major gas processing plant in Russia’s Orenburg region, damaging critical infrastructure and disrupting gas intake from Kazakhstan.
The Orenburg plant, operated by Gazprom, is one of the world’s largest gas processing facilities, handling gas condensate from Kazakhstan’s Karachaganak field.
Ukrainian forces claim to have hit Russia’s Novokuibyshevsk oil refinery in the Samara region, damaging its main refining units.
Russia responded by launching 62 drones into Ukrainian territory, with 40 reportedly shot down or diverted.
Russia’s air defenses intercepted 45 Ukrainian drones, including 12 over Samara, one over Orenburg, and 11 over Saratov.
Ukrainian prosecutors allege that Russia is using a new rocket-powered bomb, the UMPB-5R, capable of traveling up to 130 kilometers, to strike civilian areas in Kharkiv’s Lozava district.
U.S. President Donald Trump suggested that Ukraine may need to surrender territory in exchange for peace, indicating a shift from previous support for Ukrainian territorial restoration.
Trump expressed hesitation about supplying Ukraine with Tomahawk missiles, citing U.S. national defense needs and concerns about weapon stock depletion.
There are ongoing hopes for diplomatic progress at a potential summit between Trump, Putin, and Zelenskyy in Hungary, though no major breakthroughs are expected.

articles.title: Nevada Labor Unions Push for Film Tax Credits to Attract Hollywood to Las Vegas
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Nevada labor unions, including the Laborers’ International Union of North America and the Nevada Jobs Now political action committee, are pushing for a special legislative session to approve tax credits for Sony Pictures Entertainment and Warner Bros. Discovery to build Summerlin Studios in West Las Vegas. The proposed $4.5 billion development, including 10 movie stages, hotels, and a medical center, would create 19,000 construction jobs and attract film tourism. Advocates argue that film production would bring new types of visitors and boost the local economy, similar to Georgia’s success with film incentives. However, critics like the AFSCME union argue the plan is fiscally irresponsible, generating only $0.52 in tax revenue per dollar spent, and could jeopardize public services. The proposal faces strong opposition due to its high cost and potential impact on state budgets, despite its potential to transform Las Vegas as a destination for film and tourism.
keyTakeAways: Nevada labor unions are advocating for tax credits to attract Hollywood film production to the state, aiming to boost tourism and job creation.
The proposed project, Summerlin Studios, would include 10 movie stages, hotels, a medical center, and a mixed-use development in West Las Vegas, with a total investment of $4.5 billion over 15 years.
Sony Pictures Entertainment and Warner Bros. Discovery are the main production companies involved, and they would be eligible for tax credits after the studio is built and filming begins.
The state would need to spend $400 million on construction and $1.8 billion on development to qualify for tax credits, which are estimated to cost $1.8 billion over time.
Nevada’s proposal is being compared to Atlanta’s successful film industry growth, which has boosted tourism and jobs, though at a significant fiscal cost.
A report by the state cites a return of only $0.52 in tax revenue for every $1 spent on tax credits, raising concerns about fiscal responsibility.
The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) opposes the plan, arguing it diverts funds from public services like education, health care, and wildfire mitigation.
The labor union Nevada Jobs Now has raised over $1 million for advocacy efforts, including digital ads and mailers, to promote the film industry proposal.

articles.title: China Accuses U.S. NSA of Cyberattacks on National Time Center
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: China accused the U.S. National Security Agency of conducting a series of cyberattacks on its National Time Service Center, claiming that the attacks—starting in 2022 and continuing through 2024—used vulnerabilities in foreign messaging apps and 42 types of advanced cyber weapons to steal data and infiltrate internal systems. The center, responsible for national time standards, supports critical sectors like finance, power, and defense, making it a high-value target. China argued that the U.S. is hypocritical in accusing China of cyber threats, implying that the U.S. itself engages in such behavior. This incident could further escalate tensions between the two nations, especially amid existing trade, technology, and Taiwan-related disputes, and the U.S. Embassy has not yet responded.
keyTakeAways: China accused the U.S. National Security Agency of conducting cyberattacks on its National Time Service Center, claiming the attacks could disrupt critical national infrastructure including communications, finance, and power supply.
The attacks allegedly involved exploiting vulnerabilities in foreign mobile phone messaging services to steal data from staff in 2022, without specifying the phone brand.
The U.S. agency reportedly used 42 types of 'special cyberattack weapons' to target internal systems of the time center during 2023–2024.
China emphasized that the time center is responsible for generating and distributing national standard time and supports critical sectors such as communications, finance, defense, and transportation.
China criticized U.S. claims of Chinese cyber threats, arguing that the U.S. itself engages in similar behaviors, suggesting hypocrisy in accusations.
The incident could escalate tensions between the U.S. and China, especially amid existing trade, technology, and Taiwan-related disputes.

articles.title: U.S. Warns of Hamas Violation of Gaza Ceasefire Amid Trump's Mixed Rhetoric

The U.S. has committed to protecting civilians and upholding the ceasefire integrity in response. Despite Trump’s earlier threats to take military action against Hamas, he clarified that U.S. troops would not be deployed into Gaza, signaling a shift from nonchalance to active diplomatic and political concern. The article highlights ongoing tensions within the U.S. stance on the conflict, as well as the precarious balance of the ceasefire in the face of potential escalation.

The U.S. has committed to taking measures to protect civilians in Gaza and preserve the integrity of the ceasefire if Hamas proceeds with the attack.

President Donald Trump previously warned on social media that he would take military action against Hamas if it continued killing civilians in Gaza, though he later clarified that no U.S. troops would be sent into Gaza.

articles.title: Trump Announces Repatriation of Two Survivors After Caribbean Drug Vessel Strike
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a major escalation of U.S. military operations in the Caribbean, President Donald Trump announced that two survivors of a military strike on a suspected drug-carrying submersible vessel have been repatriated to their home countries, Ecuador and Colombia. The vessel, reportedly carrying fentanyl and other narcotics, was targeted on a well-known trafficking route to the U.S., with the U.S. claiming at least 29 deaths, including one additional fatality. The operation is being justified by Trump as part of an 'armed conflict' with drug cartels, invoking legal precedents from the George W. Bush era. Colombian President Gustavo Petro confirmed that a detained Colombian national is alive and will be prosecuted. Legal experts have raised serious concerns about the constitutionality and international law implications of treating drug traffickers as enemy combatants. Meanwhile, Congress has expressed unease over the lack of transparency and congressional authorization for these strikes, with bipartisan calls for oversight. The actions also extend to broader geopolitical efforts, such as alleged covert operations against Venezuela’s President Nicolás Maduro.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump announced that two survivors of a U.S. military strike on a suspected drug-carrying submersible vessel in the Caribbean have been repatriated to their home countries—Ecuador and Colombia.
The U.S. military strike resulted in at least 29 deaths, with one additional fatality reported compared to earlier reports, including one confirmed death of a Colombian national.
The operation involved a vessel allegedly loaded with fentanyl and other illegal narcotics, navigating a well-known narcotrafficking transit route toward the United States.

Trump justified the strikes by invoking the framework of an 'armed conflict' with drug cartels, drawing legal parallels to the George W. Bush administration's 'war on terrorism' and claiming authority to use lethal force and detain suspects as enemy combatants.
Colombian President Gustavo Petro confirmed the survival and return of a detained Colombian national, stating that he will be prosecuted under national law.
Ecuador's government has not yet confirmed plans for repatriation of a national detained in the operation.

Legal scholars have raised concerns about the constitutionality and international law implications of treating drug traffickers as enemy combatants, especially given the lack of formal declaration of war or congressional authorization.
The administration has been criticized for conducting military strikes without sufficient congressional oversight, sparking bipartisan concern among members of Congress.

Trump's broader foreign policy actions, including potential covert operations against Venezuela's President Nicolás Maduro, further highlight the controversial nature of the administration's approach to regional security and drug trafficking.
The U.S. military released a brief video showing the strike, featuring explosions and a submersible vessel, which increased public visibility and scrutiny of the operation.

articles.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan agree to immediate ceasefire, mediated by Qatar and Turkey
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire, mediated by Qatar and Turkey, after months of escalating violence along their 2,611-kilometer border. The agreement, which came into effect on October 19, 2025, prohibits both countries from launching attacks on each other or supporting militant groups. It also includes a commitment to refrain from targeting civilians, security forces, or critical infrastructure. A follow-up meeting is scheduled for October 25 in Istanbul to review implementation. The closure of key border crossings such as Torkham and Chaman has severely affected refugees and trade, with humanitarian and economic consequences. Key officials, including Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid and Pakistani Defense Ministers Muhammad Yaqoob and Khawaja Asif, confirmed the agreement, highlighting the role of international mediation. The deal marks a critical step in de-escalating a longstanding conflict rooted in territorial disputes and cross-border militancy.
keyTakeAways: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire mediated by Qatar and Turkey.
The truce prohibits both countries from launching hostile actions against each other or supporting groups that carry out attacks on the other’s territory.
The agreement includes a mutual commitment to refrain from targeting security forces, civilians, and critical infrastructure.
A future mechanism under the mediation of intermediary countries will be established to review bilateral claims and ensure implementation.
The Durand Line, the 2,611-kilometer border between the two nations, remains a source of tension, with trade and movement severely restricted.
The Torkham and Chaman border crossings are currently closed, affecting refugees and businesses dependent on cross-border trade.
Afghanistan denies harboring militants responsible for attacks in border areas, while Pakistan cites increased militancy since 2021, following the Taliban’s return to power.

articles.title: China’s Leadership Convenes Key Plenum to Finalize Next Five-Year Economic Plan Amid Global Tensions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: China’s leadership, led by President Xi Jinping, is convening a closed-door fourth plenum in Beijing to finalize the country’s next five-year economic plan (2026–2030). The meeting occurs amid escalating trade tensions with the United States, particularly due to U.S. export controls and tariffs, prompting China to prioritize technological self-sufficiency—especially in artificial intelligence and semiconductors. Despite a projected GDP growth target of around 5%, domestic challenges such as a collapsing property sector, youth unemployment at nearly 19%, and suppressed consumer spending remain significant. Experts emphasize that while current policies are incremental, bolder measures are needed to boost consumption and address structural imbalances. The outcome of the plenum will shape China’s economic trajectory and reinforce its strategic ambitions in global technology and economic power amid rising geopolitical friction.

A major focus of the plan is achieving technological self-sufficiency, especially in artificial intelligence and advanced semiconductors, due to increasing U.S. restrictions.
Domestic challenges such as declining consumer spending, a collapsing property market, and demographic pressures (e.g., youth unemployment at nearly 19%) are key concerns.
Economic growth targets remain around 4.8% to 5%, but experts suggest that bolder policy measures are needed to boost consumption and stabilize demand.

Leadership priorities include curbing industrial overcapacity, increasing investment in consumer-related sectors (e.g., childcare, appliances), and maintaining political legitimacy through sustained economic performance.

articles.title: Israel, Hamas Clash Over Hostage Remains Amid Ceasefire Tensions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, amid a fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hamas, the two sides continue to grapple with the recovery of deceased hostages. Hamas has handed over the remains of 12 of the 28 missing Israeli hostages, with one identified as Eliyahu Margalit, a 76-year-old from Nir Oz. Israel, under Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, has maintained control over the Rafah crossing, keeping it closed since May 2024, citing delays in remain handovers. The U.S. has expressed concern, warning that a planned Hamas attack on civilians would violate the ceasefire and lead to escalated action. Gaza’s Health Ministry reports over 68,000 Palestinian deaths, with thousands still missing, and humanitarian aid remains severely restricted due to border closures. Families across Israel continue to rally in Tel Aviv, demanding the return of all deceased relatives. Hamas accuses Israel of continuing attacks and violations of the ceasefire, while both sides face challenges related to unexploded ordnance, transparency, and trust in casualty counts.
keyTakeAways: Hamas has handed over the remains of 12 of the 28 deceased hostages from Gaza, a key development in the ceasefire process.
Israel has announced that the Rafah crossing will remain closed until further notice, citing Hamas' slow release of remains.
The U.S. State Department has issued a warning that Hamas’ planned attack on civilians would constitute a violation of the ceasefire and could lead to retaliatory measures.
A total of 135 Palestinian bodies have been returned by Israel to Gaza under the ceasefire agreement, with identification efforts ongoing and no names released initially.
Hamas claims that unexploded ordnance and military control of Gaza's areas are hindering the retrieval of remains.
The Palestinian death toll has surpassed 68,000 according to Gaza’s Health Ministry, with thousands still missing and no official Israeli toll provided.
Hamas accuses Israel of violating the ceasefire through continued military actions, including killings of civilians in Gaza.
The Rafah crossing closure has severely limited aid access and medical travel for Gazans, with U.N. agencies and humanitarian groups calling for urgent reopening.
Families of missing hostages are demanding the return of all deceased relatives, with protests and rallies continuing in Tel Aviv.
The U.S. has expressed concern over potential violations of the ceasefire, with President Donald Trump warning of renewed war if hostages' remains are not returned.

articles.title: Ceasefire in Gaza Faces First Major Test Amid Aid Halt and Hostage Remains Disputes
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The fragile U.S.-proposed ceasefire in Gaza faced its first major test when Hamas militants killed two Israeli soldiers, prompting Israel to launch deadly strikes and temporarily halt aid deliveries. Despite the escalation, Israel resumed enforcement of the ceasefire and restored aid deliveries the next day. Hamas accused Israel of ceasefire violations and claimed communication with its units in Rafah had been severed, while Israel accused Hamas of failing to return all 28 deceased hostages. Only 25 bodies have been identified by Gaza’s Health Ministry, with Israel releasing 150 bodies, some of which are decomposed and missing limbs. A senior Egyptian official reported ongoing round-the-clock negotiations to de-escalate tensions, and Hamas has reaffirmed its refusal to join a postwar governing body in Gaza. The U.S. remains silent on immediate developments, while the ceasefire's long-term success hinges on disarming Hamas, Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, and establishing a Palestinian-led administrative structure. The humanitarian toll remains severe, with at least 36 Palestinians, including children, killed in strikes and Gaza facing a prolonged famine and aid blockade.
keyTakeAways: The fragile ceasefire in Gaza was severely tested when Hamas militants killed two Israeli soldiers, prompting a wave of Israeli military strikes and a temporary halt in aid deliveries.
Hamas accused Israel of ceasefire violations, while Israel claimed Hamas had fired on troops in Israeli-controlled areas of Rafah, leading to a breakdown in trust.
Israel resumed enforcing the ceasefire and resumed aid deliveries to Gaza on Monday, following the incident.
Hamas has handed over the remains of 12 hostages, but Israel claims it still has more bodies and insists on the return of all 28 deceased hostages.
Only 25 bodies have been identified by Gaza’s Health Ministry, with Israel not identifying or confirming how the bodies died.
A senior Egyptian official reported ongoing 'round-the-clock' contacts to de-escalate tensions, indicating Egypt's role as a key mediator.
The U.S.-proposed ceasefire aims to end two years of war, with future phases including disarming Hamas, Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, and establishing a Palestinian technocratic government.
Hamas has rejected participation in a postwar ruling authority and instead advocated for a body of Palestinian technocrats to manage daily affairs.
Humanitarian conditions remain dire: at least 36 Palestinians, including children, were killed in strikes, and Gaza faces a severe famine and lack of aid after a two-month aid cutoff.
Israel has released 150 Palestinian bodies, including 15 on Sunday, with photos posted online for families to identify loved ones.

articles.title: Supreme Court Affirms Fundamental Right to Privacy in Surveillance Cases
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a landmark decision, the Supreme Court of India ruled that the fundamental right to privacy is a constitutional right protected under Article 21 of the Constitution. The court examined cases involving state surveillance and technology-driven monitoring, emphasizing that such practices must be justified and proportionate. It held that indiscriminate or unconsented surveillance violates the right to privacy and that the state must have a legitimate reason and a transparent process to conduct surveillance. The court also stressed the importance of establishing a legislative framework to regulate the use of technology in surveillance, ensuring that any state action remains within constitutional boundaries. This judgment has significant implications for digital privacy, law enforcement, and the balance of power between the state and individuals in India.
keyTakeAways: The court emphasized that the right to privacy is protected under Article 21 of the Indian Constitution, and any interference with this right must be justified and proportionate.
The judgment clarified that the use of technology for surveillance, especially without consent, may infringe upon the fundamental right to privacy.
The court held that the state cannot conduct indiscriminate surveillance, and must have a legitimate reason and a transparent process to justify such actions.
The ruling reinforced the need for legislative frameworks to regulate the use of technology in surveillance to ensure compliance with constitutional rights.

articles.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Agree to Ceasefire Amid Deadly Border Conflict
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire after more than a week of deadly cross-border fighting, mediated by Qatar and Turkey. The conflict, rooted in accusations of cross-border terrorism and violations of sovereignty, escalated when Pakistan conducted airstrikes in Afghanistan’s Paktika province targeting militant groups like Hafiz Gul Bahadur. The strikes killed at least 10 civilians, including three local cricketers, prompting widespread condemnation, a cricket boycott by Afghanistan’s national board, and international outcry from the ICC. The Taliban accused Pakistan of violating Afghan sovereignty, while Pakistan’s army chief urged mutual security. Despite the ceasefire, experts warn that the core issue—Taliban denial of responsibility for militant activity and the disputed Durand Line—remains unresolved, threatening long-term regional instability.
keyTakeAways: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire after more than a week of deadly cross-border fighting.
The conflict, considered the deadliest in several years, involves accusations of cross-border terrorism and violations of sovereignty.

Afghan officials and the Taliban condemned the attacks, accusing Pakistan of violating Afghan sovereignty and engaging in deliberate aggression.
The national cricket board of Afghanistan has boycotted an upcoming series in Pakistan following the deaths of young players.
The International Cricket Council expressed sorrow over the deaths of three promising Afghan cricketers.
Qatar and Turkey acted as mediators to facilitate the ceasefire negotiations.
The Durand Line, the 2,611-kilometer border between the two nations, remains a source of contention as Afghanistan has never officially recognized it.
The core issue remains unresolved: the Taliban's denial of responsibility for cross-border militant activity and Pakistan’s insistence on targeting militant groups like Hafiz Gul Bahadur.
Experts warn that without sustained diplomatic efforts, the conflict could resurface, threatening regional stability and the resurgence of extremist groups like ISIS and al-Qaeda.

articles.title: Indiana University Fires Student Newspaper Adviser and Ends Print Editions Amid Censorship Allegations
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Indiana University has sparked a national controversy by eliminating the print editions of its student newspaper, the Indiana Daily Student, and firing its faculty adviser Jim Rodenbush for refusing to remove news stories from a homecoming edition. While the university claims the move is financially driven and part of a transition to digital media, student journalists and legal experts argue that it constitutes censorship and violates the First Amendment, as student editors, not faculty advisors, hold editorial control. The Indiana Daily Student, long recognized as one of the best collegiate publications, continues publishing online, maintaining editorial independence. The incident has drawn strong criticism from advocates, including billionaire Mark Cuban and legal experts from the Student Press Law Center, who say public universities like Indiana University should uphold student media freedom. This conflict raises broader questions about academic autonomy, financial sustainability, and the role of student journalism in democratic society.

The university claims the move is financially motivated and part of a broader shift toward digital platforms, but critics see it as censorship and a 'scare tactic' targeting student journalism.
The Indiana Daily Student has a history of being recognized as one of the best collegiate publications and receives $250,000 annually from the university's Media School.

articles.title: Moroccan Youth Protest Against Stadium Spending, Demand for Education and Healthcare Reforms
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In Morocco, youth-led protests under the Gen Z 212 movement continue to gain momentum, with demonstrators demanding the removal of Prime Minister Aziz Akhannouch and calling for urgent reforms in education and healthcare. The protests, which erupted after a tragic childbirth incident in Agadir, have intensified as young people condemn government spending on new stadiums for the 2030 FIFA World Cup and the upcoming Africa Cup of Nations, asserting that such investments come at the expense of vital public services. Protesters chant slogans like 'Stadiums are here, but where are the hospitals?' and have called for a boycott of soccer events. The movement, organized on platforms like Discord, highlights deep societal inequalities, including disparities in education access and rural infrastructure, and has led to arrests, injuries, and violent clashes. Despite King Mohammed VI’s speech promoting balanced development, the lack of direct engagement with protest demands has fueled public skepticism, signaling a growing youth-led political movement challenging elite governance and social priorities.
keyTakeAways: Moroccan youth, organized under the Gen Z 212 movement, are protesting against corruption, underfunded education, and deteriorating public healthcare.
Protesters are demanding the removal of Prime Minister Aziz Akhannouch, accusing him of prioritizing sports infrastructure over basic social services.
A central slogan is 'Stadiums are here, but where are the hospitals?', highlighting a perceived contradiction in national spending priorities.
The protests are inspired by similar movements in Nepal and are fueled by real grievances such as teacher shortages, transportation issues, and disparities between public and private schools.
Since 2000, private university enrollment in Morocco has increased more than sixfold, raising concerns about unequal access to quality education.
Government audits have identified regional disparities and service gaps, especially in rural areas, undermining trust in public systems.
Protesters have called for a boycott of the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations, scheduled for December, as a symbolic rejection of stadium-focused spending.
Following violent protests in Agadir, where eight women died during childbirth, the movement gained national momentum and resulted in arrests and court convictions.

The King, Mohammed VI, did not directly address the protests in a recent parliamentary speech, instead promoting the coexistence of national projects and social programs, which many interpret as a retreat from political accountability.

articles.title: Pope Leo XIV Canonizes Venezuela’s 'Doctor of the Poor' as First National Saint
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pope Leo XIV canonized José Gregorio Hernández, a beloved Venezuelan doctor known as the 'doctor of the poor,' marking Venezuela’s first saint and a significant moment of national celebration amid deep economic crisis, political instability, and rising tensions with the United States. The ceremony, which drew an estimated 70,000 people and was attended by thousands more watching from Caracas, was approved by the late Pope Francis from his hospital room, bypassing the usual miracle confirmation process due to widespread veneration. The event also included the canonization of six other saints, including Peter To Rot from Papua New Guinea and several religious figures, reinforcing global Catholic unity. The canonization serves as both a spiritual and cultural affirmation of resilience, particularly in the face of years of poverty, emigration, and foreign political pressure.
keyTakeAways: José Gregorio Hernández, a Venezuelan doctor known as the 'doctor of the poor,' was canonized by Pope Leo XIV, becoming Venezuela’s first saint and a symbol of national resilience.
The canonization took place during a time of severe economic crisis, political instability, and rising tensions with the United States, offering a moment of national hope and unity.
The process was accelerated by Pope Francis, who approved the canonization based on widespread veneration rather than a miracle, reflecting a shift in canonization criteria.
Venezuela’s first saint is a deeply symbolic act, uniting the nation around a shared moral and religious identity amid political and economic turmoil.
The event also included the canonization of six other saints, including Peter To Rot of Papua New Guinea and Bartolo Longo, emphasizing global Catholic solidarity.

articles.title: Julian Sayin’s Dominant Performance Strengthens Heisman Case as Ohio State Shuts Out Wisconsin
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ohio State’s quarterback Julian Sayin delivered a dominant performance, going 36-of-42 for 393 yards and three touchdowns in a 34-0 victory over Wisconsin. His 80% completion rate and ability to deliver in critical third-down situations have elevated his status as a serious Heisman Trophy contender. Receiver Carnell Tate, who caught six of Sayin’s passes and scored two touchdowns, praised Sayin as a 'Heisman winner' with no doubt. Ohio State, ranked No. 1 in the AP Top 25, has an undefeated start and a strong defense allowing only 5.9 points per game. Wisconsin, struggling with a 2-5 record and back-to-back shutouts, faced a crushing loss due to poor offensive output, injuries to key players, and a defensive breakdown. The article highlights Ohio State’s rise in the national rankings and Wisconsin’s continued challenges, with both teams facing high-profile matchups in the upcoming weeks.

Title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China

China has accused the United States of “double standards” after US President Donald Trump threatened to impose an additional 100 percent tariff on Chinese goods in response to Beijing’s curbs on exports of rare earth minerals.

China says its export control measures  announced  last week were in response to the US restrictions on its entities and targeting of Beijing’s maritime, logistics and shipbuilding industries.

Trump’s tariff threats, which come weeks before the likely meeting between the US president and his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, have the potential to reignite a trade war, months after Washington lowered the China tariffs from 125 to 30 percent.

The actions by the world’s two largest economies threaten to ignite a new trade war, adding further uncertainty to global trade. So what’s the recent history of US trade measures against China, and will the two countries be able to resolve their differences?

On October 9, China expanded export controls to cover 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals and certain refining equipment, effective December 1, after accusing Washington of harming China’s interests and undermining “the atmosphere of bilateral economic and trade talks”.

China also placed restrictions on the export of specialist technological equipment used to refine rare-earth metals on Thursday.

Beijing justified its measures, accusing Washington of imposing a series of trade curbs on Chinese entities despite the two sides being engaged in trade talks, with the last one taking place in Madrid, Spain, last month.

Foreign companies now need Beijing’s approval to export products containing Chinese rare earths, and must disclose their intended use. China said the heightened restrictions come as a result of national security interests.

China has a near monopoly over rare earths, critical for the manufacture of technology such as electric cars, smartphones, semiconductors and weapons.

The US is a major consumer of Chinese rare earths, which are crucial for its defence industry.

At the end of this month, Trump and Xi are expected to meet in South Korea, and experts speculate that Beijing’s move was to gain a bargaining advantage in trade negotiations with Washington.

China’s tightening of restrictions on rare earths is “pre-meeting choreography” before Trump’s meeting with Xi, Kristin Vekasi, the Mansfield chair of Japan and Indo-Pacific Affairs at the University of Montana, told Al Jazeera.

On October 10, Trump announced the imposition of a 100 percent tariff on China, effective from November 1.

“Based on the fact that China has taken this unprecedented position … the United States of America will impose a Tariff of 100 percent on China, over and above any Tariff that they are currently paying,” Trump wrote in a post on his Truth Social platform.

He added that this would come into effect on November 1 or before that. Trump added that the US would also impose export controls on “any and all critical software”.

Earlier on October 10, Trump accused China of “trade hostility” and even said he might scrap his meeting with Xi. It is unclear at this point whether the meeting will take place.

“What the United States has is we have a lot of leverage, and my hope, and I know the president’s hope, is that we don’t have to use that leverage,” US Vice President JD Vance told Fox News on Sunday.

China deemed the US retaliation a “double standard”, according to remarks by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce spokesperson on Sunday.

China said Washington had “overstretched the concept of national security, abused export control measures” and “adopted discriminatory practices against China”.

“We are living in an era of deeper intertwining of security and economic policies. Both the US and China have expanded their conceptions of national security, encompassing a range of economic activities,” Manoj Kewalramani, chairperson of the Indo-Pacific Studies Programme at the Takshashila Institution in Bangalore, India, told Al Jazeera.

“Both have also weaponised economic interdependence with each other and third parties. There are, in other words, no saints in this game.”

Kewalramani said China started expanding the idea of “national security” much earlier than others, especially with its “comprehensive national security concept” introduced in 2014.

Through this, China began to include many different areas, such as economics, technology, and society, under the term “national security”. This shows that China was ahead of other countries in broadening what counts as a national security issue.

China threatened additional measures if Trump went ahead with his pledge.

“Willful threats of high tariffs are not the right way to get along with China. China’s position on the trade war is consistent: We do not want it, but we are not afraid of it,” the Chinese Commerce Ministry spokesperson said in a statement.

“Should the US persist in its course, China will resolutely take corresponding measures to safeguard its legitimate rights and interests,” the statement said.

“US policy explicitly targets Chinese firms linked to the military or advanced technology sectors. Whether that’s justified national security screening or discrimination is a matter of framing, but the policy design is undeniably China-specific,” Vekasi said.

A month after taking office for his second term, Trump signed an executive order imposing a 10 percent tariff on all imports from China, citing a trade deficit in favour of China. In this order, he also imposed tariffs on Mexico and Canada. China levied countermeasures, imposing duties on US products in retaliation.

In March, the US president doubled the tariff on all Chinese products to 20 percent as of March 4. China imposed a 15 percent tariff on a range of US farm exports in retaliation; these took effect on March 10.

Trump announced his  “reciprocal tariffs” , imposing a 34 percent tariff on Chinese products. China retaliated, also announcing a 34 percent tariff on US products. This was the first time China announced export controls on rare earths.

Hours after the reciprocal tariffs went into effect, Trump paused them for all his tariff targets except China. The US and China continued to hike tit-for-tat levies on each other.

Trump slapped 145 percent tariffs on Chinese imports, prompting China to hit back with 125 percent tariffs. Washington and Beijing later cut tariffs to 30 percent and 10 percent, respectively, in May, then agreed to a 90-day truce in August for trade talks. The truce has been extended twice.

In December 2024, Trump’s predecessor, former US President Joe Biden, tightened controls on the sale of microchips first introduced in October 2022.

Under the new controls, 140 companies from China, Japan, South Korea and Singapore were added to a list of restricted entities. The US also banned more advanced chip-making equipment to certain countries. Even products manufactured abroad with US technology were restricted.

Biden signed a bill into law that would ban TikTok unless it was sold to a non-Chinese buyer within a year. The US government alleged that TikTok’s Chinese parent company ByteDance was linked to the Chinese government, making the app a threat to national security.

ByteDance sued the US federal government over this bill in May 2024.

In September this year, Trump announced that a deal was finalised to find a new owner of TikTok.

In October 2023, Biden restricted US exports of advanced computer chips, especially those made by Nvidia, to China and other countries.

The goal of this measure was to limit China’s access to “advanced semiconductors that could fuel breakthroughs in artificial intelligence and sophisticated computers that are critical to [Chinese] military applications”, Gina Raimondo, who was secretary of the US Department of Commerce during the Biden administration, told reporters.

Prior to this, Biden signed an executive order in August 2023, creating a programme that limits US investments in certain high-tech areas, including semiconductors, quantum computing, and artificial intelligence, in countries deemed to be a security risk, like China.

Biden restricted China’s access to US semiconductors in October 2022. The rules further expanded restrictions on chipmaking tools to include industries that support the semiconductor supply chain, blocking both access to US expertise and the essential components used in manufacturing the tools that produce microchips.

Semiconductors are used in the manufacturing of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. The US government placed these restrictions back then to limit China’s ability to acquire the ability to produce semiconductors and advance in the technological race.

The restrictions made it compulsory for entities within China to apply for licences to acquire US semiconductors. Analysis by the US-based Carnegie Endowment for International Peace described these licences as “hard to get” back then.

Recently, some US lawmakers are calling for even more restrictions, warning that China could quickly reverse-engineer advanced semiconductor technologies on its own, outpace the US in the sector, and gain a military edge.

In May 2020, the US Bureau of Industry and Security intensified rules to stop Huawei, the Chinese tech giant, from using US technology and software to design and make semiconductors in other countries.

The new rules said that semiconductors designed for Huawei using US technology or equipment, anywhere in the world, would need US government approval before being sent to Huawei.

Trump signed an executive order blocking Chinese telecommunications companies like Huawei from selling equipment in the US. The Shenzhen-based Huawei is the world’s largest provider of 5G networks, according to analysis by the New York City-based think tank the Council on Foreign Relations (CFR).

Under this order, Huawei and 114 related entities were added to a list that requires US companies to get special permission (a licence) before selling certain technologies to them.

The rationale behind this order was the allegation that Huawei threatened US national security, had stolen intellectual property and could commit cyberespionage. Some US lawmakers alleged that the Chinese government was using Huawei to spy on Americans. The US did not publicise any evidence to back these allegations.

Other Western countries had also cooperated with the US.

During his first administration, Trump imposed sweeping 25 percent tariffs on Chinese goods worth as much as $60bn. In June of 2018, Trump announced more tariffs.

China retaliated by imposing tariffs on US products. Beijing deemed Trump’s trade policies “trade bullyism practices”, according to an official white paper, as reported by Xinhua news agency.

In September 2018, Trump issued another round of 10 percent tariffs on Chinese products, which were hiked to 25 percent in May 2019.

In 2011, during US President Barack Obama’s tenure, the US-China trade deficit reached an all-time high of $295.5bn, up from $273.1bn in the previous year.

In March 2012, the US, European Union, and Japan formally complained to China at the World Trade Organization (WTO) about China’s limits on selling rare earth metals to other countries. This move was deemed “rash and unfair” by China.

In its ruling, the world trade body said China’s export restraints were breaching the WTO rules.

In 2014, the US indicted five Chinese nationals with alleged ties to China’s People’s Liberation Army. They were charged with stealing trade technology from US companies.

Trump and Xi are expected to meet in South Korea on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, which is set to begin on October 31.

But the latest trade dispute has clouded the Xi-Trump meeting.

On Sunday, Trump posted on his Truth Social platform, downplaying the threat: “Don’t worry about China, it will all be fine! Highly respected President Xi just had a bad moment. He doesn’t want Depression for his country, and neither do I. The U.S.A. wants to help China, not hurt it!!!”

In an interview with Fox Business Network on Monday, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said, “President Trump said that the tariffs would not go into effect until November 1. He will be meeting with [Communist] Party Chair Xi in [South] Korea. I believe that meeting will still be on.”

When it comes to which of the two players is more affected by the trade war, Kewalramani said he thinks “what matters is who is willing to bear greater pain, endure greater cost.

“This is the crucial question. I would wager that Beijing is probably better placed because Washington has alienated allies and partners with its policies since January. But then, China’s growing export controls are not simply aimed at the US. They impact every country. So Beijing has not also endeared itself to anyone,” Kewalramani said, pointing out how Trump’s tariffs and China’s rare earth restrictions target multiple countries.

“The ones affected the most are countries caught in the midst of great power competition.”

Vekasi from the University of Montana said both economies are absorbing real pain in different ways.

“The US can cushion the shock better because of its large domestic consumer base and still-strong upper-end spending. Inflation has hit lower-income households, but overall consumer demand remains solid,” she said.

“China, by contrast, relies more heavily on exports, and the US remains a key market. Sustained export restrictions or new tariffs could make it hard for Beijing to meet its growth targets.”

On Sunday, US VP Vance told Fox News about China: “If they respond in a highly aggressive manner, I guarantee you, the president of the United States has far more cards than the People’s Republic of China.”

Kewalramani said so far, Beijing has been more organised, prepared and strategic than the US in its policies.

“That said, it has overreached with the latest round of export controls. US policy, meanwhile, has lacked strategic coherence. The US still is the dominant global power and has several cards to play. What matters, however, is whether it can get its house in order.”

Vekasi said we are likely to see both the US and China keeping escalation tools in reserve, each claiming the upper hand. She added that how long that lasts will depend less on diplomacy and more on how the markets and broader global economy react in the coming weeks.

“Neither side wants to look like it’s backing down. The rare earth regulations give Beijing flexibility – they can be implemented slowly, signalling resolve without fully cutting off exports. Trump, meanwhile, seems to be calibrating pressure (100% tariffs! Or maybe not!) to avoid spooking markets while still projecting toughness.”

articles.title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused widespread flooding and landslides in five Mexican states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—leading to at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas include Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, where over 280mm of rain fell. The National Civil Protection Coordination reported severe damage to infrastructure, with about 100,000 homes affected and 263,000 people losing power. The Mexican military and civil agencies have launched large-scale rescue and relief operations, including aerial deliveries of food and water. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua acknowledged that no prior meteorological warnings predicted the magnitude of the rainfall, raising concerns about the effectiveness of Mexico’s early warning systems.
keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, confirmed 65 people are still missing.
The states most affected are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
Thousands of military personnel from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist in rescue and relief operations.
Around 100,000 houses have been affected, with some located near rivers reportedly 'practically disappearing' due to flooding.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which led to rapid river rise and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul, Veracruz (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla (286mm).
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply in the five affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum acknowledged that no prior meteorological warnings predicted the intensity of the rainfall, raising questions about Mexico’s early warning system.
